sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: This chapter discusses the concept of channels within &susemgr; and provides a foundational overview of managing channels within a &susemgr; network. This includes naming, base and child channel relationship, deployment and maintenance of vendor and custom channels for &susemgr; Server and &susemgrproxy; Server as well as the &susemgr; channel life cycle and various security options. This chapter also provides information about repositories, cloning, and staging with &susemgr;.

sect1.title: What are Channels?
sect1.para: Channels in &susemgr; represent the installation media for your clients. Like other media types channels contain software packages, patches and updates for your clients and provide an administrator with strict control over what may be installed on client systems. &susemgr; server allows you to manage channels easily via API or Web UI . There are three kinds of channels used within &susemgr;.

formalpara.title: SUSE Vendor Channels
formalpara.para: SUSE Vendor Channels are maintained by SUSE Linux and cannot be changed or modified.

formalpara.title: Custom Channels
formalpara.para: Custom Channels are created according to your infrastructure requirements and include specific packages relevant to your system needs. These may be changed and modified.

formalpara.title: Repositories
formalpara.para: Repositories are used to import packages from existing repositories into a software channel or channels.

sect1.title: Base Channels vs. Child Channels
sect1.para: It is important to understand the concept of base channels and their relationship to child channels when administering channels within &susemgr;. Channels are organized in a tree format in &susemgr; a base(parent) channel and multiple child channels. A client system must be assigned to a single base channel as this provides a clients main installation media. You may not have more than one base channel assigned to a client, although a single base channel may be assigned multiple child channels.
